title: Tech
description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from Tech, skipping any feeds with errors.

items.title: 12 Athletes to Watch at the 2026 Winter Olympics
items.description: History is already being made at the Milano Cortina Games—and they haven’t even started.

items.title: Fitbit founders launch AI platform to help families monitor their health
items.description: Luffu uses AI in the background to gather and organize family information, learn day-to-day patterns, and flag notable changes so families can stay al...

items.title: Peak XV says internal disagreement led to partner exits as it doubles down on AI
items.description: Peak XV is transitioning board roles and opening a U.S. office while continuing to view India as its largest market.

items.title: India’s Supreme Court to WhatsApp: ‘You cannot play with the right to privacy’
items.description: India's top court is investigating WhatsApp’s data-sharing model, monopoly power, and user consent.

items.title: All the Sports You Won’t See at the 2026 Winter Olympics
items.description: The makeup of the Winter Olympics has changed many times in the 100-plus years of the Games. Here are some sports that haven’t stood the test of time.

items.title: ‘Fallout’ Producer Jonathan Nolan on AI: ‘We’re in Such a Frothy Moment’
items.description: The Westworld showrunner thinks AI will be good for burgeoning filmmakers, but not for Hollywood blockbusters.

items.title: TikTok recovers from dip in usage that benefited rival apps following U.S. ownership change
items.description: TikTok usage dropped following ownership change, benefiting rival apps. But now, its numbers are climbing again.

items.title: PayPal hires HP’s Enrique Lores as its new CEO
items.description: PayPal is appointing CFO and COO Jamie Miller as interim CEO until March 1.

items.title: Nick Goepper’s Starter Pack: Winter Olympics 2026
items.description: What a three-time Olympic medalist packs for the Milano Cortina Winter Games.

items.title: Vema predicts cheap hydrogen could change where data centers are built
items.description: Vema Hydrogen drills wells to stimulate hydrogen production deep underground, which could result in some of the cheapest hydrogen available.
